2.1   Propositional Logic

In Discrete, you learned about Propositional Logic, which included variables (like P,Q,R) that range over true (written T) and false (written F). The variables can then be combined with operators like AND (written \land) OR (written \lor), and NOT (written \neg).

You probably did proofs that certain formulas were satisfiable (there existed some assignment of variable that made the formula T), valid (for all assignments of variable, the formula was T), falsifiable (there existed some assignment of variables that made the formula F), and invalid (for all assignments, the formula was F).

These proofs were done via truth table. For example, you could show that P \lor \neg P is valid via the following truth table:

P

P \lor \neg P

T

T

F

T

This is fine, but one goal of formal methods is to move logical reasoning into the computer, primarily to increase the reliability of the proofs that we do. For example, if we had written the above truth table as:

P

P \lor \neg P

T

T

F

F

we might think that the formula was only satisfiable (rather than valid): but this is because the second row of the truth table is wrong! F \lor \neg F is T, since \neg F is T and the truth table for \lor tells us that F \lor T is T.

How do we do better? Well, it turns out we can express propositional logic as computations over boolean values in a language like Intermediate Student Language w/ Lambda (henceforth, ISL+) that you are familiar with from Fundamentals 1. Let’s see how to do that, by building a table of equivalences between expressions in propositional logic and expressions in ISL+. Some of these are built in; others we define using lambda and other operators.

expression in logic

expression in ISL+

T

#t

F

#f

\land

and

\lor

or

\neg

not

\Rightarrow

(lambda (P Q) (and P (not Q)))

\equiv

boolean=?

\otimes

(lambda (P Q) (or (and P (not Q)) (and Q (not P))))

ite

if

Most of these operators should be familiar, but it’s possible some are not, so let’s review them, and in particular, think about why our version in ISL+ expresses the same thing.

First, T and F: expressing these as #t and #f allow us to re-use boolean operators to work as logical operators, provided that they do the same thing. In some sense, this choice was arbitrary, as long as we remember our choice: we could use #f to represent T, but if we did that we would have to be very careful when translating all the rest of the operators, and would be likely to get confused! By representing logical T as the ISL+ value #t and F as #f, we can easily reuse boolean operators from ISL+. For example, \land is defined by the following truth table:

P

Q

P \land Q

T

T

T

T

F

F

F

T

F

F

F

F

To convince ourself that boolean and from ISL+ is equivalent, we need to know that (and #t #t) evaluates to #t, (and #t #f) evaluates to #f, etc. In other words, we need to know that and, applied to booleans, behaves the same way as determined by the truth table for logical and.

We can do the same thing with \lor and \neg to show that or and not are valid encodings.

You may not remember, or possibly have not learned, the rest of the operators in the table above, so lets look at their truth tables so that the ISL+ version makes sense. First, we have logical implication. Unlike natural language implication, a logical implication P \Rightarrow Q is false only if P is T and Q is F. We can express this with the truth table:

P

Q

P \Rightarrow Q

T

T

T

T

F

F

F

T

T

F

F

T

which our expression in code captures. A logical equivalence P \equiv Q holds when P and Q are assigned the same truth value, which leads to the following truth table (and the corresponding ISL+ expression):

P

Q

P \equiv Q

T

T

T

T

F

F

F

T

F

F

F

T

Exclusive or P \otimes Q holds when exactly one of P and Q holds, which doesn’t have a built-in definition, but can be expressed using and, or, and not.

Finally, the "if-then-else" ternary (three argument) logical operator ite~ P~ Q~ R has the following truth table:

P

Q

R

ite~ P~ Q~ R

T

T

T

T

T

T

F

T

T

F

T

F

T

F

F

F

F

T

T

T

F

T

F

F

F

F

T

T

F

F

F

F

which you can verify is the same behavior as the expression if.

With this table in mind, we can translate a logical formula into an ISL+ definition, where propositional variables become parameters to the definition. Here are some examples:

formula in logic

definition in ISL+

P \land (Q \lor \neg R)

(define (P Q R)
  (and P (or Q (not R))))

P \equiv (ite~ Q~ (\neg P)~ R)

(define (P Q R)
  (boolean=? P (if Q (not P) R)))

Now that we have a way of writing down formulas, we want to have a way of writing proofs, and our goal is that our proofs are checked (else we would not gain anything!). We already have a way of doing that: unit tests. Once we have our formula as a definition, we can express our truth table as a set of unit tests—one per row.

For example, our original example P \lor \neg P can be expressed as the following definition (the name p0 is arbitrary: we need to give some name if we are to use definitions. If we wanted to avoid that, we could define them as lambda expressions, but having names to refer to the formulas makes it a lot easier!):

(define (p0 P)
  (or P (not P)))

And we can express the truth table as:

(check-expect (p0 #t) #t)
(check-expect (p0 #f) #t)

Note that, critically, if we make a mistake in one of the rows of our truth table, as above when we accidentally wrote F for the second row (i.e., wrote (check-expect (p0 #f) #f)), we will get a test failure, since our formula is actually run by our proof.
